intro: Acalypha macrostachya f. puberula, commonly known as velvetleaf or silky abutilon, is a flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions. It is characterized by its soft, hairy leaves that give it a velvety texture, and its clusters of small, pale greenish-yellow flowers. The plant typically grows as an herbaceous perennial, often reaching heights of up to 2 meters. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in shaded or semi-shaded environments. Its ornamental value comes from its attractive foliage and unique floral structure.

This plant is commonly found in tropical and subtropical regions, particularly in lowland areas with high humidity. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often associated with rainforests or secondary growth habitats. The species is also known to occur in parts of the Philippines and New Guinea. Its native distribution is largely confined to the Indo-Malayan region.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acalypha macrostachya f. puberula was mainly introduced to the coastal regions of South Africa, where it has become an invasive species. It is commonly found in disturbed habitats such as roadsides, riverbanks, and urban areas. The plant spreads rapidly through its prolific seed production and ability to thrive in a variety of soil types. It poses a threat to native vegetation by outcompeting local flora for resources. Due to its aggressive growth, it is considered a noxious weed in several areas of the region.
